(2009–10) | Misc = }} '''This Is It''' was a planned [[concert residency]] by [[Michael Jackson]] which was scheduled to begin in July 2009 and end September 29, 2009 with a second leg which was scheduled to run from January 2010 through March 2010 with a total of 50 shows.https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/michael-jacksons-this-is-it-tour-balloons-to-50-show-run-stretching-into-2010-20090312 Jackson announced This Is It at a press conference in the [[The O2 Arena|O2 Arena]], stating that it would be his final series of concerts in London. [[AEG Live]], the concert promoters, released a promotional video that took up an entire commercial break, setting a record for [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]. Initially, only 10 concerts were announced, but following public demand, 40 more concerts were added. Ticket sales broke several records and Jackson's album sales increased following the announcement; AEG Live estimated that the first 10 dates alone would have earned Jackson approximately £50 million. In preparation for the concert series, Jackson had been collaborating with high-profile figures including fashion designer [[Christian Audigier]], choreographer [[Kenny Ortega]] and bodybuilder [[Lou Ferrigno]]. Prior to Jackson's death in 2009, Allgood Entertainment sued Jackson for $40 million, claiming that he had breached an exclusivity agreement with them by agreeing to the This Is It concerts; the case was dismissed. After Jackson's death, AEG Live offered either refunds to ticket holders or a special "souvenir" ticket designed by Jackson. The cancelled shows, record-breaking ticket sales{{cite web |first=Daniel|last=Kreps |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/rockdaily/index.php/2009/03/12/michael-jacksons-this-is-it-tour-balloons-to-50-show-run-stretching-into-2010/ |title=Michael Jackson’s "This Is It!" Tour Balloons to 50-Show Run Stretching Into 2010 |publisher=''Rolling Stone'' |date=March 12, 2009 |accessdate=March 24, 2009 }}{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/7941221.stm |agency=BBC News |title= Michael Jackson announces comeback gigs |publisher= ''[[BBC]]''|date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate= November 5, 2009 |last=BBC staff }}{{cite web |url= http://www.livedaily.com/news/18434.html |author= The Livedaily Staff |work= [[LiveDaily]] |title= Michael Jackson breaking records with 50-show run in London |date= March 9, 2009 |accessdate= November 5, 2009 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100209062136/http://livedaily.com/news/18434.html |archivedate= February 9, 2010 |df= mdy-all }} and potential for a world tour{{cite web |url= http://au.news.yahoo.com/a/-/entertainment/6405947/australia-part-of-planned-jackson-tour/ |title= Australia part of planned world tour |publisher=[[Yahoo! 7]] |date= October 30, 2009 |accessdate= November 5, 2009 |last=Australia |first=Yahoo }}{{cite web |url= http://www.mtv.com/movies/news/articles/1624853/20091027/story.jhtml?rsspartner=rssColdFusion |author= The MTV Staff |work= MTV |title= This Is It Director Kenny Ortega On Michael Jackson's Final Rehearsals |date= November 5, 2009 |accessdate= September 23, 2009}} led to This Is It being termed "the greatest concert[s] that never happened."{{cite web |first=IGN |last=Staff |url=http://movies.ign.com/articles/101/1016381p1.html|title=Michael Jackson’s "This Is It!" Tour Balloons to 50-Show Run Stretching Into 2010 |publisher=''IGN'' |date=August 20, 2009 |accessdate=November 5, 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.michaeljackson.com/ru/this-is-it|title=''Jackson's This Is It This Fall'' | publisher=[[Sony]] |date=August 20, 2009 |accessdate=November 5, 2009|first=Sony |last=Staff}} [[Columbia Pictures]] acquired the footage of the rehearsals and released a [[concert film]], ''[[Michael Jackson's This Is It]],'' accompanied by a [[Michael Jackson's This Is It (album)|compilation album of the same name]]. ==Promotion and significance== {{Wikinews|Michael Jackson to make last public concerts}} Jackson announced the first 10 performances during a press conference at the O2 Arena on March 5, 2009. As many as 7,000 fans and 350 reporters awaited Jackon's arrival, many donning Jackson-related clothing.{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.co.uk/artists/michael-jackson/news/100481-jackson-set-to-announce-shows|title=Jackson set to announce shows|publisher=MTV|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} {{cite news |last= Akbar |first=Arifa |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/jacko-on-tour-this-will-be-the-final-curtain-call-i-love-you-i-love-you-all-1638497.html|title=Jacko on tour: 'This will be the final curtain call. I love you, I love you all' – News, Music |publisher=''[[The Independent]]''|date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009 | location=London}} He commented at the conference, "I just wanted to say that these will be my final show performances in London. When I say this is it, it really means this is it", adding that it was his "final curtain call", although he may have just been referring to performing in London. Organizers touted the residency as, "dramatic shows [that] promise an explosive return with a band of the highest calibre, a state-of-the-art stage show and incredible surprise [[support act]]s".{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/4944927/Michael-Jackson-announces-comeback-gigs.html |title=Michael Jackson announces comeback gigs |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''|date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009 |last= Khan|first=Urmee | location=London}} Hours before the press conference, promotional posters for the residency were displayed around London. Further promotion took up an entire [[commercial break]] period on [[ITV London]] during ''[[Dancing on Ice (Series 4)|Dancing on Ice]]'', the first time this has ever happened for a musical artist. The advert, which cost £1 million to air, was viewed by 11 million people. {{cite web |last=Griffin|first=Zoe |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/news/2009/03/04/michael-jackson-has-50-medical-tests-to-prove-he-can-manage-02-arena-dates-115875-21171604/|title=Michael Jackson has 50 medical tests to prove he can manage 02 Arena dates |publisher=''[[Daily Mirror]]''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} {{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/7925388.stm|title= 'Final curtain call' for Jackson|publisher=BBC|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009|last=Youngs |first=Ian }} {{cite web|url=http://www.mediaweek.co.uk/News/MostEmailed/888126/Michael-Jackson-takes-entire-three-half-minute-ITV-ad-slot/ |title=Michael Jackson takes entire three and a half minute ITV ad slot |publisher=www.mediaweek.co.uk|date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009|last=Barnett|first=Emma }}{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/news/2009/03/09/michael-jackson-live-dates-ad-during-dancing-on-ice-seen-by-11m-fans-115875-21184002/|title=Michael Jackson live dates ad during Dancing On Ice seen by 11m fans|publisher=''Daily Mirror''|date=March 9, 2009|accessdate=March 9, 2009}} The shows, Jackson's first significant concert events since the [[Michael Jackson: 30th Anniversary Celebration]] in 2001, had been cited as one of the year's most important musical events,{{cite news|first=Rosie|last=Swash|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2009/mar/05/michael-jackson-o2-arena|title=Michael Jackson can't fail to sell out the O2 arena|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009 | location=London}} and as the greatest comeback in the history of pop.{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1151504/Michael-Jackson-chooses-Londons-O2-arena-greatest-comeback-history.html|author=Simon Cable |work=[[Dailymail.co.uk]] |title=Michael Jackson chooses London's O2 arena for the 'greatest comeback in history'|date=November 5, 2009 |accessdate=February 21, 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/43249|title=Michael Jackson announces O2 Arena London gigs — and retirement?|publisher=''[[NME]]''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} Randy Phillips, president and chief executive of [[AEG Live]], stated that the first 10 dates would earn Jackson approximately £50 million (about US$80.1 million).{{cite news|first=Patrick |last= Foster |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article5854735.ece|title=Michael Jackson grand finale curtain-raiser|publisher=''[[The Times]]''|date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009 | location=London}} ''[[The Guardian]]'' characterized the concerts as an "astonishing comeback for a man who in recent years has been dogged by controversy", adding that Jackson still had "enormous commercial clout". The ''[[Evening Standard]]'' stated that the deal was the "showbiz coup of the decade" for AEG Live, while ''[[The Independent]]'' remarked that the finalized 50 concerts would provide London with a "much-needed" economic boost.{{cite web |first=Amar |last=Singh |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23661911-details/Detoxing+brand+Jacko/article.do |title=Detoxing Brand Jacko |publisher=''[[Evening Standard]]'' |date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate=March 24, 2009 }}{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/the-barometer-michael-jackson-angela-gheorghiu-horne-and-corden-madonna-in-fancy-dress-1649091.html |title=The Barometer: Michael Jackson; Angela Gheorghiu; Horne and Corden; Madonna in fancy dress |publisher=''The Independent'' |date=March 20, 2009 |accessdate=March 25, 2009 | location=London}} Joe Cohen, chief executive of [[Seatwave]], told [[BBC 6 Music]] that the shows would generate £1 billion for the economy.{{cite web |url=http://www.metro.co.uk/metrolife/music/article.html?Michael_Jackson_in_billion_pound_boost_to_economy&in_article_id=652877&in_page_id=25 |title=Michael Jackson in 'billion pound' boost to economy |publisher=''[[Metro (Associated Metro Limited)|Metro]]'' |date=May 8, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} ==Public interest== [[File:O2 with Canary Wharf and City of London (15007282651).jpg|right|thumb|250px|The O2 Arena, where the concerts would have been held]] Some websites offered early tickets, which the [[Association of Secondary Ticket Agents]] warned were fake. "We are warning people not to buy tickets that are not yet on sale because it is unlikely that they will receive those tickets", announced the organization's chief, Graham Burns. He concluded, "It's impossible when the dates haven't been announced to be selling tickets for something when there are no announced dates".{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/43235|title=Michael Jackson London 02 Arena ticket warning issued|publisher=''NME''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} Jackson's official website allowed fans to register early for a "pre-sale" draw. Some fans had difficulty applying, as the website could not deal with the large number of registrations—reportedly up to 16,000 applications a second.{{cite news |first=Matthew|last=Moore|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/4945911/Michael-Jackson-O2-ticket-website-attracting-16000-visits-a-second.html|title=Michael Jackson O2 ticket website attracting 16,000 visits a second |publisher=''The Daily Telegraph'' |date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009 | location=London}} In the space of 24 hours, nearly a million people from around the world registered for pre-sale tickets, enough to fill the venue 50 times over.{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/news/2009/03/06/michael-jackson-adds-10-more-dates-to-comeback-tour-115875-21177334/|title=Michael Jackson adds 10 more dates to comeback tour |publisher=''Daily Mirror'' |date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.co.uk/artists/michael-jackson/news/102275-michael-jackson-announces-dates |title=Michael Jackson Announces Dates |publisher=MTV |date=March 10, 2009 |accessdate=March 29, 2009 }} Tickets that had not even been printed were selling on auction website [[eBay]] for £300.{{cite news|first=Elizabeth |last=Day |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/mar/08/michael-jackson-profile-pop-culture |title=Off the wall but still invincible |publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=March 8, 2009|accessdate=March 8, 2009 | location=London}} Sales of Jackson's albums increased following the press conference. Overnight, sales of ''[[Off the Wall]]'' rose 200%, ''[[Bad (album)|Bad]]'' rose 110%, ''[[Dangerous (Michael Jackson album)|Dangerous]]'' rose 165% and ''[[Thriller 25]]'' rose 155%.* {{cite web |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/music/article2302221.ece |title=Jacko's album sales are backo|date=March 7, 2009 |publisher=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090310080317/http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/music/article2302221.ece |archive-date=March 10, 2009 |dead-url=yes}} The two-day pre-sale began on March 11, and 40 extra dates were added to meet high demand—five of these dates were reserved in their entirety for the public sale. More than 1.5  million fans caused two sites offering pre-sale tickets to crash within minutes of going online.{{cite web |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/showbiz/article-23660868-details/1.5m+fans+crash+sites+in+rush+for+Jacko+gig/article.do |title=1.5m fans crash sites in rush for Jacko gig |publisher=''Evening Standard'' |date=March 11, 2009 |accessdate=March 30, 2009 }} In the space of two hours, 190,000 tickets were sold.{{cite news |first=Simon |last=Cable |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1161160/Fans-fury-touts-sell-Michael-Jackson-concert-tickets-16-000-pair-black-market.html |title=Fans' fury as touts sell Michael Jackson concert tickets for up to £16,000 a pair on black market |publisher=''Daily Mail'' |date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate=March 30, 2009 | location=London}} Two million people tried to buy pre-sale tickets in the space of 18 hours.{{cite news |first=David |last=Miranda |url=http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,25175199-5006024,00.html |title=Michael Jackson doubles London shows after 2 million seek tickets |publisher=''[[Herald Sun]]'' |date=March 12, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} Veronica Schmidt of ''[[The Times]]'' stated of the reception, "Michael Jackson has floored his critics",{{cite news |first=Veronica |last=Schmidt |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/music/article5889522.ece |title=Michael Jackson sells out London concerts and adds more shows |publisher=''The Times'' |date=March 11, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} while organizers proclaimed it a "cultural phenomenon".{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7940515.stm |title=Jackson to play 50 gigs at the O2 |publisher=BBC |date=March 12, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} It was announced that Jackson would break the record for number of shows performed by an artist at a single venue, which had been set by [[Prince (musician)|Prince]], who hosted a residency at the same arena for his [[21 Nights in London: The Earth Tour]] concerts. According to Jackson's website, the following records were or would have been broken: "The biggest audience ever to see an artist in one city", "The greatest number of people to attend a series of arena shows", "The fastest ticket sales in history". Randy Phillips acknowledged that Jackson could have sold out even more dates, but this would have conflicted with other career plans.{{cite web |first=Ray |last=Waddell |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/269213/update-michael-jackson-up-to-50-london-shows |title=Update: Michael Jackson Up To 50 London Shows |publisher=''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' |date=March 12, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} On March 13, the other 50% of seats for dates 1–45 and all the seats for dates 46–50 went on sale to the general public. Within four hours, all 50 dates had sold out.* {{cite web |url=https://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Showbiz-News/Michael-Jackson-This-Is-It-Shows-At-O2-Sell-Out-After-Tickets-Go-On-General-Sale/Article/200903215240762?lpos=Showbiz_News_First_Home_Article_Teaser_Region_1&lid=ARTICLE_15240762_Michael_Jackson_This_Is_It_Shows_At_O2_Sell_Out_After_Tickets_Go_On_General_Sale |title=Jackson's Tears Of Joy As O2 Shows Sell Out |date=March 13, 2009 |publisher=[[Sky News]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090316004206/https://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Showbiz-News/Michael-Jackson-This-Is-It-Shows-At-O2-Sell-Out-After-Tickets-Go-On-General-Sale/Article/200903215240762?lpos=Showbiz_News_First_Home_Article_Teaser_Region_1&lid=ARTICLE_15240762_Michael_Jackson_This_Is_It_Shows_At_O2_Sell_Out_After_Tickets_Go_On_General_Sale |archive-date=March 16, 2009 |dead-url=yes}}} At this stage, the sales of ''[[King of Pop (album)|King of Pop]]'' were up 400% and the sales of ''[[Thriller (Michael Jackson album)|Thriller]]'' were up 200%.{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/SHOWBIZ/Music/03/13/michael.jackson.concerts.tickets/ |title=750,000 tickets for Jackson concerts sell in 4 hours |publisher=CNN |date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} Tickets appeared on eBay for as much as £10,000.{{cite news |first=Rosie |last=Swash |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/mar/13/michael-jackson-o2-arena-residency-sells-out |title=Michael Jackson's 50 dates at London's O2 arena sell out |publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} ==Preparation and concert details== The 50-concert run was originally scheduled to start on July 8, 2009 and conclude on February 24, 2010.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/8060282.stm |title=Jackson delays opening tour dates |publisher=BBC |date=May 20, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} Each of the shows would have been performed at the O2 Arena in London, which has a capacity of 23,000.{{cite web|first=Andre|last=Paine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/269278/michael-jackson-says-london-concerts-to-be-final-curtain-call|title=Michael Jackson Says London Concerts To Be 'Final Curtain Call'|publisher=''Billboard''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} New York-based fashion designer [[Zaldy]] served as head costumer, creating ten of Jackson's stage looks while the other six were created by his longtime costumers, Michael Bush and Dennis Tompkins. Jay Ruckel from La Crasia Gloves recreated Jackson's iconic single glove for the concerts.{{cite news |first=William |last=Sherman |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/money/2009/06/14/2009-06-14_theyre_still_proudly_making_it_in_nyc_manufacturing_alive__well_at_feisty_factor.html |title=Michael Jackson, Hubble Telescope draw from New York manufacturing |publisher=''[[New York Daily News]]'' |date=June 14, 2009|accessdate=June 20, 2009}} The costumes he was to wear during the shows were encrusted with 300,000 [[Swarovski crystals]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/45530|title=Extra Michael Jackson O2 Arena tickets made available|date=June 23, 2009|publisher=NME|accessdate=June 26, 2009}} In April 2009, thousands of dancers flew in from all around the world to audition from the 13th to the 15th for Jackson, who helped select the 11 finalists in person.{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/268649/michael-jackson-rehearsals-move-forward |title=Michael Jackson Rehearsals Move Forward |publisher=Billboard |date=May 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} [[Kenny Ortega]], who had collaborated with Jackson previously, was to work on the overall design and direction of concerts. Ortega said that the final product would have been a "theatrical musical experience".{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Showbiz-News/Michael-Jackson-Auditions-Dancers-For-Tour-And-Works-With-Director/Article/200905215280285 |title=Michael Jackson Gets Ready For Tour |publisher=Sky News |date=May 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/44599 |title=Michael Jackson enlists 'High School Musical' director for London O2 shows |publisher=''NME'' |date=May 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }}{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Showbiz-News/Michael-Jacksons-Comeback-Tour-12-Dancers-Picked-To-Join-Singer-On-Stage-At-Londons-O2-Aena/Article/200905315284334 |title=This Is It: Jacko Picks Comeback Gig Dancers |publisher=Sky News |date=May 19, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} According to Randy Philips, £13 million was to be spent on producing the concerts, which would have included 18–22 songs and 22 different sets. There also would have been [[Aerial dance|aerial dancing]] similar to routines by [[Cirque du Soleil]]. Carla Ferrigno told [[Reuters]] that [[Lou Ferrigno|her husband Lou]] had been helping Jackson train in advance of the shows. Jackson and Ferrigno had previously worked together.{{cite news |first=Alex |last=Dobuzinskis |url=http://blogs.reuters.com/fanfare/2009/06/19/the-hulk-trains-michael-jackson-ahead-of-london-concerts/ |title=The Hulk trains Michael Jackson ahead of London concerts |publisher=Reuters |date=June 19, 2009 |accessdate=June 19, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090621224923/http://blogs.reuters.com/fanfare/2009/06/19/the-hulk-trains-michael-jackson-ahead-of-london-concerts/ |archivedate=June 21, 2009 |df=mdy-all }} On May 20, it was announced that the first concert would be pushed back five days to July 13 and three other July dates would be rescheduled for March 2010. AEG Live said that the delay was necessary because more time was needed for dress rehearsals. The revised schedule called for 27 shows between July 13 and September 29, 2009, followed by a three-month break, before resuming in the new year with 23 more shows between January 7 and March 6, 2010. Some fans petitioned for the reversal of AEG Live's decision.{{cite web |url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/44820 |title=Michael Jackson fans launch petition over O2 Arena postponement |publisher=''NME'' |date=May 21, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} In late June, several hundred seats for each of the dates were put on sale. These seats were held back until production logistics were worked out.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/8115638.stm |title=More Jackson tickets up for sale |publisher=BBC |date=June 23, 2009 |accessdate=June 25, 2009 }} It was suggested that after the London concerts, Jackson might head to [[Australia]], [[Europe]], [[India]], [[China]], [[Hong Kong]] and [[Japan]] before moving on to North America. Randy Phillips, the CEO of [[AEG Live]], told The LA Times that Australia was part of Michael Jackson's international tour plans.{{cite web |url=http://www.take40.com/news/16590/michael-jackson-planning-australian-tour-before-his-death |title=Michael Jackson Planning Australian Tour Before His Death |publisher=Take 40 |date=June 28, 2009 |accessdate=May 6, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140504000236/http://www.take40.com/news/16590/michael-jackson-planning-australian-tour-before-his-death |archivedate=May 4, 2014 |df=mdy-all }} According to Jermaine Jackson's 2011 book ''You Are Not Alone: Michael Through a Brother's Eyes'', after the London concerts were finished, Jackson was planning to extend his deal with AEG Live which included new music, a potential three-picture movie deal, a series of one-off concert dates starting in China, a halftime slot at one of the future [[Super Bowl]] games to surpass his own halftime show at the [[Super Bowl XXVII]] in January 1993 and two more tours (one of which was to be a final reunion with his brothers based on a promise made to their [[Katherine Jackson|mother]] to see her sons perform together one last time before she passed away). After the deal was completed, he planned to take time off from musical entertainment and move on to (possibly) directing his own film ideas, such as making a feature-length motion picture based on his 1982 song "Thriller" and [[Michael Jackson's Thriller (music video)|the music video of the same name]]. It was also later revealed that [http://www.damienshields.com/michael-jacksons-halloween-special-that-never-was/ a yearly Halloween television special] based on his horror-themed songs, such as "Thriller" and "Ghosts", was part of Jackson's deal with AEG Live. In [[Trial of Conrad Murray|Conrad Murray's manslaughter trial]], David Walgren stated another one of Jackson's future plans was to open a children's hospital. This was heard in an audio tape Conrad Murray played of Jackson under the influence of propofol on May 10, 2009. His voice is barely recognisable in the recording, but he can be clearly heard saying that he wanted to build the greatest children's hospital in the world and name it after himself: The ''Michael Jackson's Children's Hospital''. Walgren also stated that while the tour was happening, Jackson wanted to buy an estate with streams, horses and animals so his three children, Prince, Paris and Blanket could live normal lives as their father performed the concerts, as he was photographed looking for a house in the United Kingdom with his children. Walgren also said that the tour would begin that summer, and Jackson could take his children out of school and bring them with him so they could see him perform in London. ===Songs prepared=== As shown in ''[[Michael Jackson's This Is It]]'', songs prepared for the concerts included "[[Wanna Be Startin' Somethin']]", "[[Jam (song)|Jam]]", "[[They Don't Care About Us]]", "[[Human Nature (Michael Jackson song)|Human Nature]]", "[[Smooth Criminal]]", "[[The Way You Make Me Feel]]", a medley of songs by [[The Jackson 5]] consisting of "[[I Want You Back]]", "[[The Love You Save]]", "[[I'll Be There (The Jackson 5 song)|I'll Be There]]" and "[[Shake Your Body (Down to the Ground)]]", "[[I Just Can't Stop Loving You]]", "[[Thriller (song)|Thriller]]", "[[Beat It]]", "[[Black or White]]", "[[Earth Song]]", "[[Billie Jean]]", and "[[Man in the Mirror]]". Later on, "[[Stranger in Moscow]]", "[[You Are Not Alone]]", "[[Don't Stop 'Til You Get Enough]]", "[[Rock with You (Michael Jackson song)|Rock with You]]", "[[Dirty Diana]]" ,"[[You Rock My World]]", "[[Dangerous (Michael Jackson song)|Dangerous]]", "[[We Are the World]]", "[[Heal the World]]" and "[[Will You Be There]]" were also confirmed to have been planned for the shows. Due to the larger than usual roster of songs, as well as time constraints, Jackson would perform some songs with one verse less than he did in previous tours (such as "Wanna Be Startin' Somethin'", "Jam", "The Way You Make Me Feel" and "Black or White"). "[[Bad (Michael Jackson song)|Bad]]" was rumored to have been reserved for select concerts. On the final dates, Jackson wanted to perform a ballad called "River Ripple", written by him, with an African choir and his children. During the final concert before "Man in the Mirror", Michael was slated to premiere a song called "Best of Joy", written and recorded in 2009 prior to Jackson's death. As of 2018, the full version of "River Ripple" remains unreleased (although snippets of the song have leaked on YouTube), while "Best of Joy" was officially released in 2010 on Jackson's first posthumous album of unreleased songs, ''[[Michael (album)|Michael]]''. ==Dates== {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" ! style="width:130px;"| Date ! style="width:130px;"| City ! *[[Orianthi|Orianthi Panagaris]] – [[guitar]] *[[Tommy Organ]] – guitar *Alex Al – [[Bass guitar|bass]] *[[Jonathan Moffett]] – [[Drum kit|drums]] *Michael Bearden – [[Keyboard instrument|keyboard]]s, Show|year=2009|publisher=YouTube}} *Nicholas Basir *[[Daniel Celebre]] (a.k.a. Da FunkyMystic) *[[Mekia Cox]] *Chris Grant (a.k.a. Kriyss Grant) *[[Misha Gabriel]] *Shannon Holtzapffel *Devin Jamieson *[[Charles Klapow]] *[[Dres Reid|Ricardo Reid]] (aka Dres Reid) *Danielle Rueda Watts *Tyne Stecklein *Timor Steffens (a.k.a. Timor Dance) {{col-3}} ;Production and other personnel *[[Kenny Ortega]] – show direction *Alif Sankey – [[Assistant producer|associate production]] *Michael Cotten – [[Production designer|production design]] *Michael Curry – production design *Michael Jackson & [[Travis Payne]] – [[choreography]] *Stacy Walker – choreography assistance *Tony Testa – choreography assistance *Patrick Woodroffe – [[Lighting designer|lighting design]] *[[David Elsewhere]] – dance coaching *Shahzad Perez - Specialty Act *Gregg Smith – [[Casting (performing arts)|casting direction]] *Karen Faye Heinze – hair and make-up *[[Zaldy Goco]] – [[Costume designer|chief of costume design]] *Michael Bush – [[Costume designer|costume design]] *Dennis Thompkins - [[Costume designer|costume design]] *[[AEG Live]] – [[Promoter (entertainment)|promotion]] *Dave Polich - synth programming {{col-end}} ==Litigation== In June 2009, concert promoter Allgood Entertainment, represented by Ira Meyerowitz and Jon Kekielek of MJlawfirm, sued Jackson for $40 million. He claimed that Jackson, through his manager [[Frank DiLeo]], had agreed to a single and a $30 million reunion concert with [[The Jackson 5]] and his sister [[Janet Jackson]]. According to the concert promoter, the alleged contractual agreement prevented Jackson from performing elsewhere before the reunion concert and for a three-month period after it. Thus, agreeing to a 50 date residency at the O2 arena was an alleged breach of the Allgood Entertainment contract. The filing company stated that AEG Live knew of the alleged agreement with Jackson and used their dominance in the industry to coerce Jackson into agreeing to the residency.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8094537.stm |title=Jackson sued over reunion concert |publisher=BBC |date=June 11, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }}{{cite news |first=Sean |last=Michaels |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/jun/12/michael-jackson-sued-o2-arena|title=Michael Jackson sued for O2 arena residency|publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=June 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 | location=London}}{{cite news |first=Sean |last=Michaels |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/may/12/michael-jackson-comeback-concerts |title=Michael Jackson comeback concerts in jeopardy? |publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=June 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 | location=London}} In August 2010, the judge dismissed the case, stating that there was no evidence of a binding agreement, no contracts were signed.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-11038050 | work=BBC News | title=Judge dismisses Jackson reunion claim | date=August 20, 2010}} The case was in limbo as of 2013.{{cite web|url=http://archive.recapthelaw.org/nysd/347380/ |title=AllGood Entertainment, Inc. et al v. Jackson et al (nysd/347380) – The RECAP Archive |publisher=Archive.recapthelaw.org |date= |accessdate=May 6, 2013}}{{cite web|author=Yazmeen |url=http://muzikfactorytwo.blogspot.com/2011/05/interview-with-patrick-allocco.html |title=Interview with Patrick Allocco- President of AllGood Entertainment ~ LET'S CALL SPADE A SPADE |publisher=Muzikfactorytwo.blogspot.com |date=May 24, 2011 |accessdate=May 6, 2013}} ==Jackson's death and refunds== {{Further|Death of Michael Jackson}} On June 25, 2009, Jackson died after going into [[cardiac arrest]] which was caused by an overdose of [[Propofol]] and [[Benzodiazepine|benzodiazepines]], eighteen days before his planned first show. AEG Live, who persuaded Jackson to sign up for the shows, faced a liability of up to £300 million and an empty venue for the next nine months.{{cite news|last=Sherwin|first=Adam|title=O2 arena counts cost as curtain closes on the greatest show of all|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article6580748.ece|publisher=The Times|date=June 26, 2009|accessdate=June 26, 2009 | location=London}} The O2 arena stated that full refunds, including all ticket service charges, would be available to those who purchased tickets through authorized agents, but that "fans will have the option to be sent the actual tickets they would have received to attend the shows in lieu of the full refunds which are being offered."{{cite web |title=UCLA Statement — Michael Jackson|url=http://www.theo2.co.uk/inside/ucla-statement-michael-jackson.html |publisher=[[The O2 Arena]] |accessdate=July 1, 2009}} Fans who bought their tickets from private sellers potentially faced difficulties. eBay recommended that purchasers contact their sellers for refunds and stated that those who used PayPal can get their money back if the purchase was made during the last 45 days,{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/8120412.stm |title=Refund issues over Jackson gigs |publisher=''BBC News'' |date=June 26, 2009 |accessdate=June 26, 2009}} then later stated that "all buyers on the site will receive a full refund for their ticket purchase".{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8122580.stm |title=eBay will refund Jackson tickets |publisher=BBC News |date=June 27, 2009 |accessdate=June 27, 2009}} ==Posthumous film and album== {{Further|Michael Jackson's This Is It|Michael Jackson's This Is It (album)}} Following Jackson's death, AEG stated that they had over "100 hours of footage of preparations and rehearsals for the shows".{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/32360110 |title=Judge OKs Jackson performance film deal |agency=Associated Press |work=[[MSNBC|MSNBC.com]] |date=August 10, 2009 |accessdate=October 2, 2009}} On August 10, 2009, Los Angeles Superior Court Judge Mitchell Beckloff approved a deal between film distributor [[Columbia Pictures]] and AEG Live for the former company to purchase and distribute rehearsal footage of Jackson for a film entitled ''[[Michael Jackson's This Is It]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/showbiz/2009-08/06/content_8532737.htm |title=Michael Jackson film deal outlined in court papers |work=ChinaDaily.com |date=August 6, 2009 |accessdate=October 2, 2009}}{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-ct-jackson11-2009aug11,0,2938755.story |author=Christopher Smith |work=[[LA Times|LA Times.com]] |title=Sony Pictures to produce Michael Jackson film |accessdate=September 21, 2009 | date=August 11, 2009}} According to court documents, Columbia paid $60 million (£35 million) for rights to the rehearsal footage.{{cite web |url=http://www.uncut.co.uk/news/michael_jackson/news/13441 |title=Michael jackson This Is It film deal agreed |work=Uncut.co.uk |date=August 8, 2009|accessdate=October 3, 2009}} The papers filed in court had reportedly stated that Jackson's estate will get 90% of the profits and that AEG Live will get the remaining 10% from the film's revenue.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/aug/11/michael-jackson-film-october-release |author=Rosie Swash |title=Michael Jackson film gets October release date |work=[[Guardian.co.uk]] |date=August 11, 2009 |accessdate=October 2, 2009 | location=London}} The film was directed by [[Kenny Ortega]] who was also the director of the live concert. It was compiled mostly from footage that was shot as reference for production discussions and was never meant to be shown publicly. Some of the music and vocals in the film were added from previous recordings, though most were from the live performance. The film was released on October 28, 2009.{{cite web |url=http://www.sonypictures.com/movies/michaeljacksonthisisit/international/ |title=This Is It Worldwide Release Dates |work=[[Sony Pictures|Sony Pictures.com]] |accessdate=September 21, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090922214515/http://www.sonypictures.com/movies/michaeljacksonthisisit/international/ |archivedate=September 22, 2009 |df=mdy-all }} An accompanying album to the film was also released. Titled ''[[Michael Jackson's This Is It (album)|This Is It]]'', the compilation was distributed internationally on October 26, and to North America the following day. The two-disc album features music "inspired from the documentary of the same name".{{cite news |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2009/09/the-michael-jackson-new-musical-onslaught-begins.html |author=Chris Lee |title=The Michael Jackson new-music onslaught begins [Updated] |work=[[The LA Times|TheLATimes.com]] |date=September 23, 2009 |accessdate=September 24, 2009}} Of the album, Sony said, "Disc one will feature the original album masters of some of Michael's biggest hits arranged in the same sequence as they appear in the film" and stated that "the disc ends with two versions of the 'never-released' '[[This Is It (Michael Jackson song)|This Is It]]' [...] This song is featured in the film's closing sequence and includes backing vocals by Michael's brothers, [[The Jacksons]] and Alvin Chea of Take 6."{{cite web |url=http://www.digitalspy.com/music/a178845/new-jackson-single-lp-to-be-released.html?imdb |title=New Jackson single, LP to be released |author=Tim Parks |date=September 23, 2009 |work=[[Digital Spy|Digital Spy.com]] |accessdate=September 24, 2009}} Sony added that the second disc will feature previously unreleased versions from Jackson's "catalogue of hits", along with a spoken word [[poem]] entitled "Planet Earth" and a 36-page commemorative booklet with "exclusive photos of Michael from his last rehearsal".{{cite web |url=http://www.theinsider.com/news/2870440_Unreleased_Michael_Jackson_Song_to_be_Revealed|author=The Insider Staff |work=[[The Insider (TV series)|TheInsider.com]] |title=Unreleased Michael Jackson Song to be Revealed |date=September 23, 2009 |accessdate=September 23, 2009}} ==See also== * [[Death of Michael Jackson]] * [[List of works published posthumously]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{other uses}} {{Redirect|0 A.D.|the video game|0 A.D. (video game)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2012}}
'''Year zero''' does not exist in the [[anno Domini]] system usually used to number years in the [[Gregorian calendar]] and in its predecessor, the [[Julian calendar]]. In this system, the year {{nowrap|[[1 BC]]}} is followed by {{nowrap|[[AD 1]]}}. However, there is a year zero in [[astronomical year numbering]] (where it coincides with the Julian year {{nowrap|1 BC}}) and in [[ISO 8601|ISO 8601:2004]] (where it coincides with the Gregorian year {{nowrap|1 BC}}) as well as in all [[Buddhist calendar|Buddhist]] and [[Hindu calendar]]s.
== Historical, astronomical and ISO year numbering systems ==
=== Historians ===
The ''[[Anno Domini]]'' era was introduced in 525 by [[Scythia Minor|Scythian]] monk [[Dionysius Exiguus]] (c. 470–c. 544), who used it to identify the years on his [[Dionysius Exiguus' Easter table|Easter table]]. He introduced the new era to avoid using the ''[[Diocletian Era|Diocletian era]]'', based on the accession of [[Roman Emperor]] [[Diocletian]], as he did not wish to continue the memory of [[Diocletianic Persecution|a persecutor of Christians]]. In the preface to his Easter table, Dionysius stated that the "present year" was "the [[consulship]] of [[Anicius Probus Iunior|Probus Junior]] [Flavius Anicius Probus Iunior]" which was also 525 years "since the incarnation of our Lord [[Jesus Christ]]".<ref name=Dionysius>{{cite web|url=http://hbar.phys.msu.su/gorm/chrono/paschata.htm|title=DIONYSIUS EXIGUUS. LIBER DE PASCHATE SIVE CYCLUS PASCHALIS|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060109025617/http://hbar.phys.msu.su/gorm/chrono/paschata.htm|archivedate=9 January 2006|df=dmy-all}}</ref> How he arrived at that number is unknown.
Dionysius did not use AD years to date any historical event. This began with the English cleric [[Bede]] (c. 672–735), who used AD years in his ''[[Historia ecclesiastica gentis Anglorum]]'' (731), popularizing the era. Bede also used a term similar to the English [[Anno Domini|before Christ]] once, but that practice did not catch on until very much later. Bede did not sequentially number [[Roman calendar#Months|days of the month]], weeks of the year, or months of the year. However, he did number many of the [[week#numerical|days of the week]] using a counting origin of one in [[Ecclesiastical Latin]]. Previous Christian histories used ''[[anno mundi]]'' ("in the year of the world") beginning on the first day of [[Creation myth|creation]], or ''anno Adami'' ("in the year of [[Adam (Bible)|Adam]]") beginning at the creation of Adam five days later (the sixth day of creation according to the [[Genesis creation narrative]]), used by Africanus, or ''anno Abrahami'' ("in the year of [[Abraham]]") beginning 3,412 years after Creation according to the [[Septuagint]], used by [[Eusebius of Caesarea]], all of which assigned "one" to the year beginning at Creation, or the creation of Adam, or the birth of Abraham, respectively. Bede continued this earlier tradition relative to the AD era.
In chapter II of book I of ''Ecclesiastical history'', Bede stated that [[Julius Caesar]] invaded Britain "in the year 693 after the building of Rome, but the sixtieth year before the incarnation of our Lord", while stating in chapter III, "in the year of Rome 798, [[Claudius]]" also invaded Britain and "within a very few days … concluded the war in … the fortysixth [year] from the incarnation of our Lord".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fordham.edu/halsall/basis/bede-book1.html|title=Ecclesiastical History of the English Nation|publisher=}}</ref> Although both dates are wrong, they are sufficient to conclude that Bede did not include a year zero between BC and AD: 798 − 693 + 1 (because the years are inclusive) = 106, but 60 + 46 = 106, which leaves no room for a year zero. The modern English term "before Christ" (BC) is only a rough equivalent, ''not'' a direct translation, of Bede's Latin phrase ''ante incarnationis dominicae tempus'' ("before the time of the lord's incarnation"), which was itself never abbreviated. Bede's singular use of 'BC' continued to be used sporadically throughout the [[Middle Ages]].
Neither the concept nor a symbol for zero existed in the system of [[Roman numerals]]. The [[Babylonian numerals#Numerals|Babylonian system]] of the BC era had used the idea of "nothingness" without considering it a number, and the Romans enumerated in much the same way. Wherever a modern zero would have been used, Bede and Dionysius Exiguus did use [[Latin]] number words, or the word ''nulla'' (meaning "nothing") alongside Roman numerals.<ref name=Dionysius/><ref>Faith Wallis, trans. ''Bede: The Reckoning of Time'' (725), Liverpool: Liverpool Univ. Pr., 2004. {{ISBN|0-85323-693-3}}.</ref><ref>''Byrhtferth's Enchiridion'' (1016). Edited by Peter S. Baker and Michael Lapidge. Early English Text Society 1995. {{ISBN|978-0-19-722416-8}}.</ref> Zero was invented in India in the sixth century, and was either transferred or reinvented by the Arabs by about the eighth century. The [[Arabic numerals|Arabic numeral]] for zero ([[0 (number)|0]]) did not enter Europe until the thirteenth century. Even then, it was known only to very few, and only entered widespread use in Europe by the seventeenth century.
The ''anno Domini'' nomenclature was not widely used in Western Europe until the 9th century, and the {{nowrap|1 January}} to {{nowrap|31 December}} historical year was not uniform throughout Western Europe until 1752. The first extensive use (hundreds of times) of 'BC' occurred in ''Fasciculus Temporum'' by [[Werner Rolevinck]] in 1474, alongside years of the world (''anno mundi'').<ref>Werner Rolevinck, ''[http://www.cervantesvirtual.com/servlet/SirveObras/80248064097793506388868/index.htm Fasciculus temporum]''.</ref> The terms ''anno Domini'', ''Dionysian era'', ''Christian era'', ''vulgar era'', and ''common era'' were used interchangeably between the [[Renaissance]] and the 19th century, at least in [[Latin]]. But ''vulgar era'' was suppressed in English at the beginning of the 20th century after ''vulgar'' acquired the meaning of "offensively coarse", replacing its original meaning of "common" or "ordinary". Consequently, historians regard all these eras as equal.
Historians have never included a year zero. This means that between, for example, {{nowrap|1 January}} {{nowrap|500 BC}} and {{nowrap|1 January}} {{nowrap|AD 500}}, there are 999 years: 500 years BC, and 499 years AD preceding 500. In common usage ''anno Domini'' 1 is preceded by the year 1 [[Ante Christum Natum|BC]], without an intervening year zero.<ref>While it is increasingly common to place ''AD'' after a date by analogy to the use of ''BC'', formal English usage adheres to the traditional practice of placing the abbreviation before the year as in Latin (e.g., {{nowrap|100 BC}}, but {{nowrap|AD 100}}).</ref> Neither the choice of calendar system (whether [[Julian calendar|Julian]] or [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]]) nor the era (''Anno Domini'' or [[Common Era]]) determines whether a year zero will be used. If writers do not use the convention of their group (historians or astronomers), they must explicitly state whether they include a year 0 in their count of years, otherwise their historical dates will be misunderstood.<ref>V. Grumel, ''La chronologie'' (1958), page 30.</ref>
=== Astronomers === {{Main article|Astronomical year numbering}}
In astronomy, for the year AD 1 and later it is common to assign the same numbers as the Anno Domini notation, which in turn is numerically equivalent to the Common Era notation. But the discontinuity between 1 AD and 1 BC makes it cumbersome to compare ancient and modern dates. So the year before 1 AD is designated 0, the year before 0 is −1, and so on.
The letters "AD", "BC", "CE, or "BCE" are omitted. So 1 BC in historical notation is equivalent to 0 in astronomical notation, 2 BC is equivalent to −1, etc. Sometimes positive years are preceded by the + sign. This year numbering notation was introduced by the astronomer Jacques Cassini in 1740.<ref>{{Cite book| edition = 3| publisher = Univ Science Books| isbn = 1-891389-85-8| editor1-first = Sean E. | editor1-last= Urban | editor2-first = P. Kenneth | editor2-last= Seidelmann | title = Explanatory Supplement to the Astronomical Almanac| chapter = Calendars | author-first = E. G. | author-last = Richards | page = 591 | location = Mill Valley, CA| date = 2013}}</ref>
==== History of astronomical usage ==== In 1627, the German astronomer [[Johannes Kepler]] first used an astronomical year which was to become year zero in his ''[[Rudolphine Tables]]''. He labeled the year ''Christi'' and inserted it between years labeled ''Ante Christum'' (BC) and ''Post Christum'' (AD) on the mean motion pages of the Sun, Moon, and planets.<ref>[http://www.ub.uni-kiel.de/digiport/bis1800/Arch3_436.html Tabulae Rudolphinae – Ioannes Keplerus] (1627) 191 (42), 197 (48), 203 (54), 209 (60), 215 (66), 221 (72), 227 (78).</ref> Then in 1702 the French astronomer [[Philippe de la Hire]] used a year he labeled {{nowrap|''Christum 0''}} at the end of years labeled ''ante Christum'' (BC), immediately before years labeled ''post Christum'' (AD) on the mean motion pages in his ''Tabulæ Astronomicæ'', thus adding the designation ''0'' to Kepler's ''Christi''.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=BjygAAAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover#PPP35,M1 Tabulae Astronomicae – Philippo de la Hire] (1702), Tabulæ 15, 21, 39, 47, 55, 63, 71; Usus tabularum 4.</ref> Finally, in 1740 the French astronomer [[Jacques Cassini]] {{nowrap|(Cassini II)}}, who is traditionally credited with the invention of year zero,<ref>Robert Kaplan, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Bn0EBVsfi1YC&pg=PA103&lpg=PA103 ''The nothing that is''] (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2000) 103.</ref> completed the transition in his ''Tables astronomiques'', simply labeling this year ''0'', which he placed at the end of years labeled ''avant Jesus-Christ'' (BC), immediately before years labeled ''après Jesus-Christ'' (AD).<ref>[Jacques] Cassini, ''Tables astronomiques'' (1740), Explication et usage 5; Tables 10, 22, 53.</ref>
=== ISO 8601 ===
[[ISO 8601|ISO 8601:2004]] (and previously ISO 8601:2000, but not ISO 8601:1988) explicitly uses astronomical year numbering in its date reference systems. Because it also specifies the use of the [[proleptic Gregorian calendar]] for all years before 1582, some readers incorrectly assume that a year zero is also included in that proleptic calendar, but it is not used with the BC/AD era. The "basic" format for year 0 is the four-digit form 0000, which equals the historical year 1 BC. Several "expanded" formats are possible: −0000 and +0000, as well as five- and six-digit versions. Earlier years are also negative four-, five- or six-digit years, which have an [[absolute value]] one less than the equivalent BC year, hence -0001 = 2 BC. Because only [[ISO 646]] (7-bit [[ASCII]]) characters are allowed by ISO 8601, the minus sign is represented by a [[hyphen-minus]].
== Other traditions ==
=== South Asian calendars === All eras used with [[Hindu calendar|Hindu]] and [[Buddhist calendar]]s, such as the [[Saka era]] or the [[Kali Yuga]], begin with the year 0. All these calendars use elapsed, expired, or complete years, in contrast with most other calendars which use current years. A complete year had not yet elapsed for any date in the initial year of the epoch, thus the number 1 cannot be used. Instead, during the first year the indication of 0 years (elapsed) is given in order to show that the epoch is less than 1 year old. This is similar to the Western method of stating a person's age – people do not reach age one until one year has elapsed since birth (but their age during the year beginning at birth is specified in months or fractional years, not as age zero). However, if ages were specified in years and months, such a person would be said to be, for example, 0 years and 6 months or 0.5 years old. This is analogous to the way time is shown on a [[24-hour clock]]: during the first hour of a day, the time elapsed is 0 hours, ''n'' minutes.
